title: mass
text:
Load the mass matrix from a FULL file.
NumPy data type to store the matrix as. The options are np.double,
np.int32, and np.int64. The default is np.double.
This parameter is only applicable if asarray=True.
AnsMath matrix name. The default is None, in which case a
name is automatically generated.
Name of the file to read the matrix from. The default is "file.full".
Whether to return a SciPy array rather than an AnsMath matrix.
The default is False.
AnsMath matrix or SciPy sparse matrix, depending on the value for
the asarray parameter.
Convert to a SciPy array.

title: svd
text:
Apply an SVD algorithm on a matrix.
The SVD algorithm is only applicable to dense matrices.
Columns that are linearly dependent on others are removed,
leaving the independent or basis vectors. The matrix is
resized according to the new size determined by the SVD algorithm.
For the SVD algorithm, the singular value decomposition of an
input matrix is a factorization of the form:
M = U*SIGMA*V.T
For more information, see Singular Value Decomposition.
Array to compress.
Numerical threshold value for managing the compression.
The default is is 1E-7.
Name of the vector for storing the SIGMA values.
Name of the vector for storing the values from v.
See the preceding equation.
Apply the SVD algorithm on an existing dense rectangular matrix, using
the default threshold. The matrix is modified in-place.

title: size
text: Number of items in this vector.

title: get_vec
text:
Load a vector from a FULL file.
NumPy data type to store the vector as. The options are np.double,
np.int32, and np.int64. The default is np.double.
AnsMath vector name. The default is None, in which case a
name is automatically generated.
Name of the file to read the vector from. The default is "file.full".
Vector ID to load. If loading from a "*.full" file,
the vector ID can be one of the following:
"RHS": Load vector
"GVEC": Constraint equation constant terms
"BACK": Nodal mapping vector (internal to user)
If this vector ID is used, the default dtype is np.int32.
"FORWARD" - Nodal mapping vector (user to internal).
If this vector ID is used, the default dtype is np.int32.
Whether to return a NumPy array rather than an AnsMath vector.
The default is False.
AnsMath vector or NumPy array vector, depending on the value for
the asarray parameter.

title: norm
text:
Return the norm of the AnsMath object.
Mathematical norm to use. The default is 'NRM2'. Options are:
'NRM2': L2 (Euclidean or SRSS) norm.
'NRM1': L1 (absolute sum) norm (vectors only).
'NRMINF': Maximum norm.
Norm of the matrix or the one or more vectors.

title: PyAnsys Math basic operations
text:
This tutorial shows how you can use PyAnsys Math for basic
operations on AnsMath vectors and matrices in the APDL memory
workspace.
Perform required imports.
Create two AnsMath vectors of size 5. The \vec{v} method is initialized with
ones, and the \vec{w} is filled with random values.
Plot the created vectors.
Like NumPy vectors, AnsMath vectors can use most of the
standard operators, such as +, -, +=, -=,
and *=.
Here this form is used: \vec{z}=\vec{v}+\vec{w}
Compute \|z\|_2. (The default norm is nrm2. Note that you
can use .norm('nrm1') or .norm('nrminf') for different normals.
For more information, see help(z.norm).
Alternatively you can use methods, following the NumPy
standards. Available methods are:
mm.add()
mm.subtract()
mm.dot()
Equivalent operator for addition:
z = v + w
Equivalent operator for subtraction:
z = v - w
Equivalent dot operation for the product of two vectors:
Perform in-place addition.
Perform in-place multiplication.
Perform another in-place multiplication.
Allocate two dense matrices with random values.
Add these 2 dense matrices and then scale the result matrix.
Transpose a matrix.
As for vectors, methods are available as an alternative to operators.
Compute a matrix vector multiplication.
AnsMath matrices can be identified by printing, viewing their types, or
using the __repr__ method by simply typing out the variable.
Here is an example with an AnsMath matrix.
Here is an example with an AnsMath vector.
Regardless of the underlying AnsMath object type, you are generally
able to perform most NumPy or SciPy operations on these arrays. You
can do this in one of two ways.
You can convert a matrix to a NumPy array.
Alternatively, you can use NumPy to compute the maximum of the array.
This works because PyAnsys Math copies over the matrix to the local
Python memory and then computes the maximum using NumPy.
While this works for most NumPy operations, keep in mind that
operations supported within PyAnsys Math (such as adding or
multiplying arrays) compute much faster because the data is not copied.
Stop PyAnsys Math.

section: Use NumPy methods on AnsMath objects
text:
Regardless of the underlying AnsMath object type, you are generally
able to perform most NumPy or SciPy operations on these arrays. You
can do this in one of two ways.
You can convert a matrix to a NumPy array.
Alternatively, you can use NumPy to compute the maximum of the array.
This works because PyAnsys Math copies over the matrix to the local
Python memory and then computes the maximum using NumPy.
While this works for most NumPy operations, keep in mind that
operations supported within PyAnsys Math (such as adding or
multiplying arrays) compute much faster because the data is not copied.

title: Use PyAnsys Math to solve eigenproblems
section: Use PyAnsys Math to solve eigenproblems
text:
This example uses a verification manual input file, but you can use
your own sparse or dense matrices.
Perform required imports.
Run the input file from Verification Manual 153 and then
get the stiff (k) and mass (m) matrices from the FULL file.
Display size of the k and m matrices.
Allocate an array to store the eigenshapes, where nev` is the number
of eigenvalues requested,
Perform the modal analysis.
The algorithm is automatically chosen with respect to the properties
of the matrices (such as scalar, storage, or symmetry).
Print the vector of eigenfrequencies.
Check the residual error for the first eigenresult:
R_1=||(K-\lambda_1.M).\phi_1||_2
First, compute \lambda_1 = \omega_1^2 = (2.\pi.f_1)^2
Then get the first eigenshape \phi_1 and compute both
K.\phi_1 and M.\phi_1.
Next, compute the ||K.\phi_1||_2 quantity and normalize the
residual value.
Add these two vectors, using the \lambda_1 scalar
factor, and compute the normalized residual value:
\frac{R_1}{||K.\phi_1||_2}
Compute this residual for all eigenmodes
Plot tahe accuracy of the eigenresults.
Stop PyAnsys Math.

import time

from ansys.mapdl.core.examples import vmfiles
import matplotlib.pylab as plt
import numpy as np

import ansys.math.core.math as pymath

# Start PyAnsys Math as a service.
mm = pymath.AnsMath()
out = mm._mapdl.input(vmfiles["vm153"])
fullfile = mm._mapdl.jobname + ".full"
k = mm.stiff(fname=fullfile)
m = mm.mass(fname=fullfile)
print(m.shape)
print(k.shape)

def get_res(i):
    """Compute the residual for a given eigenmode."""
    # Eigenfrequency (Hz)
    f = ev[i]

    # omega = 2.pi.Frequency
    omega = 2 * np.pi * f

    # lambda = omega^2
    lam = omega * omega

    # i-th eigenshape
    phi = a[i]

    # K.Phi
    kphi = k.dot(phi)

    # M.Phi
    mphi = m.dot(phi)

    # Normalize scalar value
    kphinrm = kphi.norm()

    # (K-\lambda.M).Phi
    mphi *= lam
    kphi -= mphi

    # Return the residual
    return kphi.norm() / kphinrm


pymath_acc = np.zeros(nev)

for i in range(nev):
    f = ev[i]
    pymath_acc[i] = get_res(i)
    print(f"[{i}] : Freq = {f}\t - Residual = {pymath_acc[i]}")

title: Use PyAnsys Math to solve eigenproblems > Print eigenfrequencies
Use PyAnsys Math to solve eigenproblems > Verify the accuracy of eigenresults
text:
Check the residual error for the first eigenresult:
R_1=||(K-\lambda_1.M).\phi_1||_2
First, compute \lambda_1 = \omega_1^2 = (2.\pi.f_1)^2
Then get the first eigenshape \phi_1 and compute both
K.\phi_1 and M.\phi_1.
Next, compute the ||K.\phi_1||_2 quantity and normalize the
residual value.
Add these two vectors, using the \lambda_1 scalar
factor, and compute the normalized residual value:
\frac{R_1}{||K.\phi_1||_2}
Compute this residual for all eigenmodes
# Eigenfrequency (Hz)
i = 0
f = ev[0]
omega = 2 * np.pi * f
lam = omega * omega
# shape
phi = a[0]

# APDL command: *MULT,K,,Phi,,KPhi
kphi = k.dot(phi)

# APDL command: *MULT,M,,Phi,,MPhi
mphi = m.dot(phi)
# APDL command: *MULT,K,,Phi,,KPhi
kphi = k.dot(phi)


# APDL command: *NRM,KPhi,NRM2,KPhiNrm
kphinrm = kphi.norm()
# APDL command: *AXPY,-lambda,,MPhi,1,,KPhi
mphi *= lam
kphi -= mphi

# Compute residual
res = kphi.norm() / kphinrm
print(res)
1.9136679485631705e-10
def get_res(i):
    """Compute the residual for a given eigenmode."""
    # Eigenfrequency (Hz)
    f = ev[i]

    # omega = 2.pi.Frequency
    omega = 2 * np.pi * f

    # lambda = omega^2
    lam = omega * omega

    # i-th eigenshape
    phi = a[i]

    # K.Phi
    kphi = k.dot(phi)

    # M.Phi
    mphi = m.dot(phi)

    # Normalize scalar value
    kphinrm = kphi.norm()

    # (K-\lambda.M).Phi
    mphi *= lam
    kphi -= mphi

    # Return the residual
    return kphi.norm() / kphinrm


pymath_acc = np.zeros(nev)

for i in range(nev):
    f = ev[i]
    pymath_acc[i] = get_res(i)
    print(f"[{i}] : Freq = {f}\t - Residual = {pymath_acc[i]}")

title: factorize
text:
Factorize a matrix.
Perform the numerical factorization of a linear solver system: (A*x=b).
By default, factorization modifies the input matrix mat
in place. This behavior can be changed using the inplace parameter.
AnsMath matrix.
Factorization algorithm. Options are "LAPACK" and "DSP".
The default is "LAPACK" for dense matrices and "DSP" for
sparse matrices.
Whether the factorization is performed on the input matrix
rather than on a copy of this matrix. Performing factorization on
a copy of this matrix would result in no changes to the input
matrix. The default is True.
Factorize a random matrix and solve a linear system.

title: Compute Eigenvalues using PyAnsys Math and SciPy
section: Compute Eigenvalues using PyAnsys Math and SciPy
text:
This example shows how to perform these tasks:
Extract the stiffness and mass matrices from an MAPDL model.
Use PyAnsys Math to compute the first eigenvalues.
Get these matrices using SciPy to obtain the same
solutions using Python resources.
See if PyAnsys Math is more accurate and faster than SciPy.
Perform required imports.
Load the input file using MAPDL.
Plot and mesh using the eplot method.
Set up a modal analysis and form the K and M matrices.
MAPDL stores these matrices in a .FULL file.
Read the sparse matrices using PyAnsys Math.
Solve the eigenproblme using PyAnsys Math.
Print the eigenfrequencies and the accuracy.
Accuracy : \frac{||(K-\lambda.M).\phi||_2}{||K.\phi||_2}
Get the MAPDL sparse matrices into Python memory as SciPy
matrices.
Make the sparse matrices for SciPy unsymmetric because symmetric matrices
in SciPy are memory inefficient.
K = K + K^T - diag(K)
Plot the matrices.
Solve the eigenproblem.
Convert lambda values to frequency values:
freq = \frac{\sqrt(\lambda)}{2.\pi}
Compute the residual error for SciPy.
Err=\frac{||(K-\lambda.M).\phi||_2}{||K.\phi||_2}
Plot residual error to see if PyAnsys Math is more accurate than SciPy.
Plot elapsed time to see if PyAnsys Math is more accurate than SciPy.
Stop PyAnsys Math.

    phi = vecs.T[i]  # i-th eigenshape

    kphi = pk * phi.T  # K.Phi
    mphi = pm * phi.T  # M.Phi

    kphi_nrm = np.linalg.norm(kphi, 2)  # Normalization scalar value

    mphi *= lam  # (K-\lambda.M).Phi
    kphi -= mphi

    scipy_acc[i] = 1 - np.linalg.norm(kphi, 2) / kphi_nrm  # compute the residual
    print(f"[{i}] : Freq = {freqs[i]:8.2f} Hz\t Residual = {scipy_acc[i]:.5}")

title: Compute Eigenvalues using PyAnsys Math and SciPy > Use SciPy to solve the same eigenproblem
section: Use SciPy to solve the same eigenproblem
text:
Get the MAPDL sparse matrices into Python memory as SciPy
matrices.
Make the sparse matrices for SciPy unsymmetric because symmetric matrices
in SciPy are memory inefficient.
K = K + K^T - diag(K)
Plot the matrices.
Solve the eigenproblem.
Convert lambda values to frequency values:
freq = \frac{\sqrt(\lambda)}{2.\pi}
Compute the residual error for SciPy.
Err=\frac{||(K-\lambda.M).\phi||_2}{||K.\phi||_2}
pk = k.asarray()
pm = M.asarray()

# get_ipython().run_line_magic('matplotlib', 'inline')

fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2)
fig.suptitle("K and M Matrix profiles")
ax1.spy(pk, markersize=0.01)
ax1.set_title("K Matrix")
ax2.spy(pm, markersize=0.01)
ax2.set_title("M Matrix")
plt.show(block=True)
pkd = scipy.sparse.diags(pk.diagonal())
pK = pk + pk.transpose() - pkd
pmd = scipy.sparse.diags(pm.diagonal())
pm = pm + pm.transpose() - pmd
fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2)
fig.suptitle("K and M Matrix profiles")
ax1.spy(pk, markersize=0.01)
ax1.set_title("K Matrix")
ax2.spy(pm, markersize=0.01)
ax2.set_title("M Matrix")
plt.show(block=True)
t3 = time.time()
vals, vecs = eigsh(A=pK, M=pm, k=10, sigma=1, which="LA")
t4 = time.time()
scipy_elapsed_time = t4 - t3
print("\nElapsed time to solve this problem : ", scipy_elapsed_time)
Elapsed time to solve this problem :  2.208683490753174
freqs = np.sqrt(vals) / (2 * math.pi)
scipy_acc = np.zeros(nev)

for i in range(nev):
    lam = vals[i]  # i-th eigenvalue
    phi = vecs.T[i]  # i-th eigenshape

    kphi = pk * phi.T  # K.Phi
    mphi = pm * phi.T  # M.Phi

    kphi_nrm = np.linalg.norm(kphi, 2)  # Normalization scalar value

    mphi *= lam  # (K-\lambda.M).Phi
    kphi -= mphi

    scipy_acc[i] = 1 - np.linalg.norm(kphi, 2) / kphi_nrm  # compute the residual
    print(f"[{i}] : Freq = {freqs[i]:8.2f} Hz\t Residual = {scipy_acc[i]:.5}")

title: mgs
text:
Apply the Modified Gram-Schmidt (MGS) algorithm to a matrix.
The MGS algorithm is only applicable to dense matrices.
Columns that are linearly dependent on others are removed,
leaving the independent or basis vectors. The matrix is
resized according to the new size determined by the algorithm.
Array to apply the Modified Gram-Schmidt algorithm to.
Numerical threshold value for managing the compression.
For the MGS algorithm, the default value is 1E-14.
Apply the MGS algorithm on an existing dense rectangular matrix,
using the default threshold. The AnsMath matrix is modified in-situ.

title: Contribute
text:
Overall guidance on contributing to a PyAnsys library appears in the
Contributing topic
in the PyAnsys Developers Guide. Ensure that you are thoroughly familiar
with this guide before attempting to contribute to PyAnsys Math.
The following contribution information is specific to PyAnsys Math.
Run this code to clone and install the latest version of PyAnsys Math in development mode:
Use the PyAnsys Math Issues page to submit questions,
report bugs, and request new features. When possible, use these issue
templates:
Bug report template
Feature request template
If your issue does not fit into one of these categories, create your own issue.
To reach the project support team, email pyansys.core@ansys.com.
To build the PyAnsys Math documentation locally, in the root directory of the repository, run:
Documentation for the latest stable release of PyAnsys Math is hosted at
PyAnsys Math Documentation.
In the upper right corner of the documentations title bar, there is an option for
switching from viewing the documentation for the latest stable release to viewing
the documentation for the development version or previously released versions.
PyAnsys Math follows the PEP8 standard as outlined in the PyAnsys Development Guide and implements style checking using
pre-commit.
To ensure your code meets minimum code styling standards, run this code:
You can also install this as a pre-commit hook by running this code:
This way, its not possible for you to push code that fails the style checks:
git clone https://github.com/ansys/pyansys-math
cd pyansys-math
python -m pip install --upgrade pip
pip install -e .
pip install .[doc]
.\doc\make.bat html
pip install pre-commit
pre-commit run --all-files
pre-commit install
$ pre-commit install
$ git commit -am "added my cool feature"

git clone https://github.com/ansys/pyansys-math
cd pyansys-math
python -m pip install --upgrade pip
pip install -e .

pre-commit.
To ensure your code meets minimum code styling standards, run this code:
You can also install this as a pre-commit hook by running this code:
This way, its not possible for you to push code that fails the style checks:

title: Use PyAnsys Math to solve a dense matrix linear system
section: Use PyAnsys Math to solve a dense matrix linear system
text:
This example shows how to use PyAnsys Math to solve a dense matrix linear system.
Allocate a dense matrix in the MAPDL workspace.
Copy the matrices as NumPy arrays before they are modified by
a factorization call.
Solve the dense matrix linear system using PyAnsys Math.
Get the norm of the PyAnsys Math solution.
Solve the dense matrix linear system using NumPy.
Plot the elapsed times for PyAnsys Math and Numpy to solve the dense
matrix linear system.
Get the norm of the NumPy solution.
Stop PyAnsys Math.
Total running time of the script: (0 minutes 0.365 seconds)
Download Jupyter notebook: solve_dense_matrix.ipynb
Download Python source code: solve_dense_matrix.py
Download zipped: solve_dense_matrix.zip
Gallery generated by Sphinx-Gallery
# Perform required imports and start PyAnsys
# ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
# Perform required imports.

import time

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy.linalg as npl

import ansys.math.core.math as pymath

# Start PyAnsys Math as a server.
mm = pymath.AnsMath()
mm._mapdl.clear()
dim = 1000
a = mm.rand(dim, dim)
b = mm.rand(dim)
x = mm.zeros(dim)
a_py = a.asarray()
b_py = b.asarray()
print(f"Solving a ({dim} x {dim}) dense linear system using PyAnsys Math...")

t1 = time.time()
s = mm.factorize(a)
x = s.solve(b, x)
t2 = time.time()
pymath_time = t2 - t1
print(f"Elapsed time to solve the linear system using PyAnsys Math: {pymath_time} seconds")
Solving a (1000 x 1000) dense linear system using PyAnsys Math...
Elapsed time to solve the linear system using PyAnsys Math: 0.042484283447265625 seconds
mm.norm(x)
1.000000000000001
print(f"Solving a ({dim} x {dim}) dense linear system using NumPy...")

t1 = time.time()
x_py = npl.solve(a_py, b_py)
t2 = time.time()
numpy_time = t2 - t1
print(f"Elapsed time to solve the linear system using NumPy: {numpy_time} seconds")
Solving a (1000 x 1000) dense linear system using NumPy...
Elapsed time to solve the linear system using NumPy: 0.024129390716552734 seconds
max_time = max(pymath_time, numpy_time)
fig = plt.figure(figsize=(12, 10))
ax = plt.axes()
x = ["PyAnsys Math", "NumPy"]
y = [pymath_time, numpy_time]
plt.title("Elapsed time to solve the linear system")
plt.ylim([0, max_time + 0.2 * max_time])
plt.ylabel("Elapsed time (s)")
ax.bar(x, y, color="orange")
plt.show()
npl.norm(x_py)
np.float64(0.9999999999999996)

title: AnsMath sparse matrices and SciPy sparse matrices
section: AnsMath sparse matrices and SciPy sparse matrices
text:
This example shows how to get AnsMath sparse matrices into SciPy
sparse matrices.
Perform required imports.
Run the input file from Verification Manual 153 and then
get the stiff (k) matrix from the FULL file.
Copy the AnsMath sparse matrix to a SciPy CSR matrix. Then, plot the
graph of the sparse matrix.
You can access the three vectors that describe this sparse matrix with:
pk.data
pk.indices
pk.indptr
For more information, see SciPys class description for the
CSR (compressed sparse row) matrix.
Create an AnsMath sparse matrix from a SciPy sparse CSR matrix.
Then, transfer the SciPy CSR matrix back to PyAnsys Math.
While this code uses a matrix that was originally within MAPDL, you can
load any CSR matrix into PyAnsys Math.
Check that the matrices k and my_mat are exactly the sames. The
norm of the difference should be zero.
Printing the list of objects for the CSR representation in the PyAnsys Math
space finds these objects:
Two SMAT objects, corresponding to the k, MSub matrices,
with encrypted names.
The my_mat SMAT object. Its size is zero because the three
vectors are stored separately.
The three vectors of the CSR my_mat structure: MY_MAT_PTR,
MY_MAT_IND, and MY_MAT_DATA.
To determine which PyAnsys Math object corresponds to which Python object,
access the id property of the Python object.
Stop PyAnsys Math.

from ansys.mapdl.core.examples import vmfiles
import matplotlib.pylab as plt

import ansys.math.core.math as pymath

# Start PyAnsys Math as a service.
mm = pymath.AnsMath()
out = mm._mapdl.input(vmfiles["vm153"])
fullfile = mm._mapdl.jobname + ".full"
k = mm.stiff(fname=fullfile)
pk = k.asarray()
plt.spy(pk, color="orange", markersize=3)
plt.title("AnsMath sparse matrix")
plt.show()
print(pk.data[:10])
print(pk.indices[:10])
print(pk.indptr[:10])

text:
Provides the AnsMath solver class.
AnsSolver.axpy(obj, val1, val2)
Perform the matrix operation: self= val1*obj + val2*self.

Set all values of the object to a constant.
AnsSolver.copy()
Get the name of the copy of this object.

Factorize a matrix.

Calculates the Kronecker product of two matrices/vectors

Return the norm of the AnsMath object.

Set all values of the object to one.

Set all values of the object to a random number.

Alternatively, install the latest
PyAnsys Math GitHub package
with this command:

package locally. The changes that you make are reflected in your setup
after restarting the Python kernel.

title: PyAnsys Math documentation
text:
PyAnsys Math aims to gather all mathematical calculation tools present
in Ansys software.
This Python library allows you to access and manipulate large sparse matrices
and solve a variety of eigenproblems. It is presented in a similar manner to
the popular NumPy and SciPy libraries.
The command set for PyAnsys Math is based on tools for manipulating large mathematical
matrices and vectors that provide access to standard linear algebra operations and the
powerful sparse linear solvers of Ansys Mechanical APDL (MAPDL), providing the ability
to solve eigenproblems.
Python and MATLAB eigensolvers are based on the publicly available
LAPACK libraries and provide reasonable solve times for eigenproblems
with relatively small degrees of freedom (DOF), perhaps 100,000.
However, Ansys solvers are designed for the scale of hundreds of
millions of DOF, providing a variety of situations where you can
directly leverage Ansys high-performance solvers on a variety of
eigenproblems. Fortunately, you can leverage this without relearning
an entirely new language because PyAnsys Math is written in a similar manner
as the NumPy and SciPy libraries. For example, here is a comparison between
the NumPy and SciPy linear algebra solvers and the PyAnsys Math solver:
NumPy and SciPy
PyAnsys Math
PyAnsys Math uses the MAPDL solver in the background. It is based on the
launch_mapdl() method from PyMAPDLs ansys-mapdl-core
package.
Because PyMAPDL is gRPC-based, the MAPDL solver can function as
a server, ready to respond to connecting clients. With gRPC establishing
secure connections, a client app can directly call methods on a potentially
remote MAPDL instance as if it were a local object. The use of HTTP/2 makes
gRPC friendly to modern internet infrastructures. This, along with the use
of binary transmission formats, favors higher performance.
Here is a brief example of how you use PyAnsys Math:
For comprehensive PyAnsys Math examples, see ref_pymath_examples.
k_py = k + sparse.triu(k, 1).T
m_py = m + sparse.triu(m, 1).T
n = 10
ev = linalg.eigsh(k_py, k=neqv, M=m_py)
k = mm.matrix(k_py, triu=True)
m = mm.matrix(m_py, triu=True)
n = 10
ev = mm.eigs(n, k, m)
import ansys.math.core.math as pymath

mm = pymath.AnsMath()

u = mm.ones(5)
v = mm.rand(5)
w = u + v

print(w)

title: PyAnsys Math documentation > Introduction
text:
PyAnsys Math aims to gather all mathematical calculation tools present
in Ansys software.
This Python library allows you to access and manipulate large sparse matrices
and solve a variety of eigenproblems. It is presented in a similar manner to
the popular NumPy and SciPy libraries.
The command set for PyAnsys Math is based on tools for manipulating large mathematical
matrices and vectors that provide access to standard linear algebra operations and the
powerful sparse linear solvers of Ansys Mechanical APDL (MAPDL), providing the ability
to solve eigenproblems.
Python and MATLAB eigensolvers are based on the publicly available
LAPACK libraries and provide reasonable solve times for eigenproblems
with relatively small degrees of freedom (DOF), perhaps 100,000.
However, Ansys solvers are designed for the scale of hundreds of
millions of DOF, providing a variety of situations where you can
directly leverage Ansys high-performance solvers on a variety of
eigenproblems. Fortunately, you can leverage this without relearning
an entirely new language because PyAnsys Math is written in a similar manner
as the NumPy and SciPy libraries. For example, here is a comparison between
the NumPy and SciPy linear algebra solvers and the PyAnsys Math solver:
NumPy and SciPy
PyAnsys Math
k_py = k + sparse.triu(k, 1).T
m_py = m + sparse.triu(m, 1).T
n = 10
ev = linalg.eigsh(k_py, k=neqv, M=m_py)
k = mm.matrix(k_py, triu=True)
m = mm.matrix(m_py, triu=True)
n = 10
ev = mm.eigs(n, k, m)

title: PyAnsys Math documentation > Background
text:
PyAnsys Math uses the MAPDL solver in the background. It is based on the
launch_mapdl() method from PyMAPDLs ansys-mapdl-core
package.
Because PyMAPDL is gRPC-based, the MAPDL solver can function as
a server, ready to respond to connecting clients. With gRPC establishing
secure connections, a client app can directly call methods on a potentially
remote MAPDL instance as if it were a local object. The use of HTTP/2 makes
gRPC friendly to modern internet infrastructures. This, along with the use
of binary transmission formats, favors higher performance.

title: PyAnsys Math documentation > Quick code
text:
Here is a brief example of how you use PyAnsys Math:
For comprehensive PyAnsys Math examples, see ref_pymath_examples.
import ansys.math.core.math as pymath

mm = pymath.AnsMath()

u = mm.ones(5)
v = mm.rand(5)
w = u + v

print(w)

title: Manipulate AnsMath vectors or dense matrices as NumPy arrays
section: Manipulate AnsMath vectors or dense matrices as NumPy arrays
text:
This example demonstrates how to use NumPy arrays to exchange data between PyAnsys Math
and Python.
This example requires Ansys 2021 R2 or later.
Allocate an AnsMath vector with 10 doubles.
Create a NumPy array from this AnsMath vector.
Note that these are two separate objects. Memory is
duplicated. Modifying one object does not modify its clone.
You can manipulate this NumPy array with all existing NumPy
features.
Alternatively, the AnsMath object can be operated on directly with
using NumPy methods.
Note that some methods have APDL corollaries, and these methods are
more efficient if performed within PyAnsys Math.
For example, the norm method can be performed within PyAnsys Math.
You can push back any NumPy vector or 2D array to PyAnsys Math. This
creates a new AnsMath vector, which in this case is named "NewVec:.
Create a Python handle to this vector by specifying its name.
You can apply the same features to dense APDL matrices and NumPy arrays.
Allocate an AnsMath dense matrix.
Convert the AnsMatch dense matrix to a NumPy array.
Use the matrix method to load the NumPy array to APDL.
Load this matrix from APDL and verify it is identical.
Stop PyAnsys Math.
